name: Retrofuturism: aesthetic impact of space design on screen culture
description: Humans have long imagined the future, including prospective travel to space and what living life away from planet earth could look like. This extending to designing interiors of domestic spaces and how these have then influenced the aesthetics of screen culture through set building and design.

key_work.title: Heavenly Bodies
key_work.brief_description: Rather than thinking of space as a cold, dark vacuum, 2pt Interactive’s Heavenly Bodies embraces the warm, domestic interiors of 1970s Soviet space architecture.

end.title: Production design in Heavenly Bodies
end.brief_description: Inspired by the work of Soviet space architect Galina Balashova, the interiors of Heavenly Bodies feel inviting – colour-coding creates a sense of orientation, and the illusion of a roof and floor, despite the zero-gravity environment.

end.brief_description: Meet George Jetson and his quirky family: wife Jane, son Elroy and daughter Judy. Living in the automated, push-button world of the future hasn’t made life any easier for the harried husband and father, who gets into one comical misadventure after another!

links.description: The animation style of The Jetsons, the 60s American cartoon, created an iconic aesthetic that meshed mid-century modern and futuristic architecture, much like the influences on Heavenly Bodies. It predicted and imagined what the nuclear family unit may function like in the year 2062.

start.title: Barbarella [DVD]
start.creator_credit: Roger Vadim, Dino De Laurentiis, De Laurentiis Entertainment Group and Marianne Productions
start.brief_description: This cult film by New Wave director Roger Vadim begins with a flawlessly executed zero gravity strip-tease by the film’s feisty 41st century space adventurer, Barbarella (Jane Fonda). The adventure begins when the president of Earth contacts Barbarella for her help in locating Durand Durand (Milo O’Shea), a young scientist who has vanished with a deadly positronic ray that contains the power to “shatter the loving union of the universe”. Her mission takes an unexpected twist after her fur-lined vessel makes a forced landing on the icy planet Lythion after being rocked by a magnetic disturbance. Barbarella soon faces a number of challenging situations that result in many costume changes, and pleasurable encounters with the handsome men who assist her as she continues to track the elusive Durand Durand. With the help of the angel, Pygar (John Phillip Law), Barbarella must infiltrate the city of SoGo and battle the Black Guards and the Great Tyrant - a sadistic seductress who wants Barbarella for her own devious purposes - to recover the devastating weapon and restore peace and order to the galaxy. Based on the French science-fiction comic by Jean-Claude Forest, with dazzling and inventive costume design by Jacques Fonteray and Paco Rabanne.

end.title: The Girl from Tomorrow. Ep 1-3
end.creator_credit: Noel Price, Film Australia, Nine Network and Kathy Mueller
end.brief_description: Alana, a lively 13 year old from the year 3000, finds herself stranded in a strange and primitive world when a time-travel experiment goes terribly wrong. She is kidnapped by Silverthorn, a fugitive war-lord from the dangerous and violent times of the year 2500 and they crash land in a rubbish dump in Sydney in the year 1990. Alana crawls from the battered time capsule, leaving Silverthorn unconscious, and escapes with her personal wrist computer P.J. as her only companion. Cold, hungry and frightened, she is discovered by Jenny, a rebellious purple-haired girl her own age and Petey, Jenny’s science fiction obsessed younger brother.

links.description: Released in 1991, The Girl From Tomorrow was Film Australia’s first sci-fi TV show. It follows 13-year-old Alana, who, after an experiment gone wrong, travels back in time (like Barbarella) from the year 3000 to 1990s Australia.
